procedures.title: Our Treatments
procedures.subtitle: Comprehensive endovascular and interventional treatments organized by specialty

categories.name: Neurovascular
categories.description: Advanced minimally invasive treatments for brain aneurysms, stroke, and cerebrovascular conditions.

treatments.title: Cerebral Aneurysm Embolization
treatments.shortDescription: Minimally invasive treatment for brain aneurysms using advanced coiling and flow diversion techniques.
treatments.fullDescription: Cerebral aneurysm embolization is a minimally invasive procedure to treat weakened, bulging areas in brain blood vessels. Using catheters navigated through blood vessels from the groin, we deploy platinum coils or flow diverters to seal off the aneurysm, preventing rupture and hemorrhagic stroke without open brain surgery.
benefits: No open brain surgery or skull removal required
Tiny incision in the groin - less than 5mm
Return to normal activities in 1-2 weeks
Lower risk than surgical clipping for many aneurysm types
treatments.recovery: Most patients stay overnight for observation. Mild groin discomfort for 2-3 days. Return to work and normal activities within 1-2 weeks. Follow-up angiography at 3, 6, and 12 months to confirm aneurysm occlusion.

treatments.title: Acute Stroke Revascularization
treatments.shortDescription: Emergency mechanical thrombectomy to restore blood flow during acute ischemic stroke.
treatments.fullDescription: Acute stroke revascularization (mechanical thrombectomy) is an emergency procedure to remove blood clots blocking brain arteries during an acute ischemic stroke. Using catheter-based devices, we physically extract the clot to restore blood flow, dramatically improving outcomes when performed within 6-24 hours of symptom onset.
benefits: Effective up to 24 hours after symptom onset in selected patients
Can be combined with clot-busting medications
treatments.recovery: Recovery depends on stroke severity and timing of treatment. Patients typically stay in hospital for 3-7 days. Rehabilitation including physical, occupational, and speech therapy often begins during hospitalization. Full recovery may take weeks to months.

treatments.title: Carotid Artery Stenting
treatments.shortDescription: Stent placement to open narrowed carotid arteries and prevent stroke.
treatments.fullDescription: Carotid artery stenting is a minimally invasive procedure to treat carotid artery stenosis (narrowing), a major cause of stroke. We place a small mesh tube (stent) in the narrowed artery to keep it open, using embolic protection devices to catch any debris and prevent stroke during the procedure.
benefits: Prevents stroke by improving blood flow to the brain
Smaller incision than traditional carotid surgery
Lower risk of nerve injury and wound complications
treatments.recovery: Overnight observation in hospital. Most patients return to normal activities within a few days. Dual antiplatelet medications are required for at least 3 months. Regular ultrasound follow-up at 1, 6, and 12 months.

treatments.title: Chronic Subdural Hematoma Embolization
treatments.shortDescription: MMA embolization to treat and prevent recurrent chronic subdural hematoma.
treatments.fullDescription: Chronic subdural hematoma (cSDH) embolization treats collections of blood on the brain's surface by blocking the middle meningeal artery (MMA) that supplies the hematoma membrane. This stops bleeding and prevents recurrence, often avoiding the need for surgical drainage or reducing recurrence after drainage.
benefits: Non-surgical alternative to burr hole drainage
Significantly reduces recurrence rates from 30% to under 5%
Can be done under local anesthesia
Highly effective for recurrent cSDH cases
treatments.recovery: Most patients discharged same day or next day. Mild headache possible for 2-3 days. Follow-up CT scans at 4-8 weeks show hematoma resolution. Success rate exceeds 90% for preventing recurrence.

treatments.title: Brain AVM & Dural Fistula Treatment
treatments.shortDescription: Endovascular embolization for arteriovenous malformations and dural arteriovenous fistulas.
treatments.fullDescription: We treat brain arteriovenous malformations (AVM) and dural arteriovenous fistulas (dAVF) using embolization - injecting special materials to block abnormal blood vessel connections. Our trans-venous approach can reach complex lesions through the venous system when arterial access is challenging.
benefits: Minimally invasive alternative to open surgery
Can treat deep-seated lesions unreachable by surgery
May cure the lesion or reduce size before radiosurgery
treatments.recovery: Hospital stay of 1-3 days depending on complexity. Recovery varies based on lesion size and location. Follow-up angiography at 3-6 months. Some AVMs may require staged treatments or adjunctive radiosurgery.

categories.name: Neuromodulation
categories.description: Implantable device therapies for movement disorders, sleep apnea, and neurological conditions.

treatments.title: Deep Brain Stimulation (DBS)
treatments.shortDescription: Neuromodulation therapy for Parkinson's disease, movement disorders, and psychiatric conditions.
treatments.fullDescription: Deep Brain Stimulation (DBS) involves implanting electrodes in specific brain areas to deliver electrical impulses that regulate abnormal brain activity. FDA-approved for Parkinson's disease, essential tremor, dystonia, and obsessive-compulsive disorder. Emerging applications include depression and post-stroke recovery.
benefits: Significant reduction in Parkinson's motor symptoms
Reduces medication needs and related side effects
Improves quality of life and daily function
Effective when medications become less effective
treatments.recovery: Hospital stay of 1-2 days for implantation. Device programming begins 2-4 weeks after surgery. Regular follow-up visits for optimization. Battery typically lasts 3-5 years and is replaced in a minor procedure.

treatments.title: Hypoglossal Nerve Stimulation
treatments.shortDescription: Implantable device therapy for moderate-to-severe obstructive sleep apnea.
treatments.fullDescription: Hypoglossal nerve stimulation (Inspire therapy) treats obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) by stimulating the nerve that controls tongue movement. During sleep, the implanted device delivers mild stimulation to prevent the tongue from blocking the airway, activated by a handheld remote before sleep.
benefits: Improves sleep quality and daytime alertness
treatments.recovery: Outpatient surgical procedure. Soft diet for 2-3 weeks. Device activated after 1 month. Sleep study at 2 months to optimize settings. Most patients see significant improvement within the first few months.

categories.name: Urogenital & Pelvic
categories.description: Minimally invasive treatments for uterine fibroids, prostate enlargement, varicose veins, and pelvic conditions.

treatments.title: Uterine Fibroid Embolization
treatments.shortDescription: Non-surgical treatment for uterine fibroids causing heavy bleeding and pain.
treatments.fullDescription: Uterine artery embolization (UAE) treats symptomatic uterine fibroids by blocking blood flow to the fibroids, causing them to shrink. Small particles are injected through a catheter to occlude the uterine arteries while preserving the uterus. Highly effective for heavy menstrual bleeding and bulk symptoms.
benefits: Highly effective for heavy bleeding (90% success)
treatments.recovery: Same-day discharge. Cramping for 2-3 days managed with medication. Return to normal activities within 1-2 weeks. MRI at 3-6 months confirms fibroid shrinkage by 40-60%.

treatments.title: Prostate Artery Embolization
treatments.shortDescription: Minimally invasive treatment for enlarged prostate (BPH) urinary symptoms.
treatments.fullDescription: Prostate artery embolization (PAE) treats benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) by blocking blood flow to the prostate gland, causing it to shrink. This relieves urinary symptoms including frequency, urgency, weak stream, and nighttime urination without the risks of TURP surgery or sexual side effects.
benefits: No catheter or only brief catheterization
treatments.recovery: Same-day discharge. Mild pelvic discomfort for 2-3 days. Temporary urinary symptoms may worsen initially. Improvement begins at 2-4 weeks with maximum benefit at 3-6 months.

treatments.title: Pelvic Congestion & Varicocele Embolization
treatments.shortDescription: Vein embolization for pelvic congestion syndrome and male varicocele.
treatments.fullDescription: Ovarian vein embolization treats pelvic congestion syndrome (chronic pelvic pain due to varicose veins in the pelvis) by blocking refluxing ovarian veins. Varicocele embolization treats enlarged scrotal veins causing pain and infertility. Both procedures offer minimally invasive alternatives to surgery.
treatments.recovery: Same-day discharge. Mild pelvic/groin discomfort for 1-2 days. Return to work within 2-3 days. Symptom improvement over 2-4 weeks. Follow-up ultrasound at 3 months confirms vein occlusion.

treatments.title: Varicose Vein Treatment
treatments.shortDescription: Advanced minimally invasive options for varicose veins and chronic venous insufficiency.
treatments.fullDescription: We offer comprehensive varicose vein treatment including endovenous laser ablation (EVLA), radiofrequency ablation (RFA), mechanochemical ablation (MOCA), ultrasound-guided foam sclerotherapy, and ambulatory phlebectomy. These treatments close or remove faulty veins, redirecting blood flow to healthy veins.
treatments.recovery: All procedures are outpatient. Wear compression stockings for 1-2 weeks. Walking encouraged immediately. Minor bruising resolves in 1-2 weeks. Follow-up ultrasound at 6 weeks.

categories.name: Gastrointestinal
categories.description: Non-surgical treatments for hemorrhoids and other GI conditions.

treatments.title: Hemorrhoidal Artery Embolization
treatments.shortDescription: Non-surgical treatment for symptomatic internal hemorrhoids.
treatments.fullDescription: Hemorrhoidal artery embolization (HAE) treats bleeding internal hemorrhoids by blocking the arterial blood supply. Small coils or particles are injected into the superior rectal arteries, reducing blood flow to the hemorrhoids and causing them to shrink. No cutting or removal of tissue.
treatments.recovery: Same-day discharge. Mild rectal pressure for 1-2 days. Bleeding typically stops within days and resolves within 1-2 weeks. Avoid heavy lifting for 1 week. High success rate over 80%.

categories.name: Musculoskeletal
categories.description: Innovative embolization treatments for knee arthritis and chronic foot pain.

treatments.title: Genicular Artery Embolization
treatments.shortDescription: Targeted embolization for knee osteoarthritis pain.
treatments.fullDescription: Genicular artery embolization (GAE) treats chronic knee pain from osteoarthritis by reducing inflammation in the knee joint. Tiny particles block abnormal blood vessels in the knee lining that contribute to inflammation and pain, offering relief for patients not ready for knee replacement surgery.
benefits: Delays or avoids knee replacement surgery
treatments.recovery: Same-day discharge. Mild knee discomfort for 2-3 days. Pain relief typically begins within 2-4 weeks as inflammation subsides. Maximum benefit at 3 months. Success rate of 70-80% for pain reduction.

treatments.title: Plantar Fasciitis Embolization
treatments.shortDescription: Minimally invasive treatment for chronic plantar fasciitis heel pain.
treatments.fullDescription: Plantar fasciitis embolization (PFE) treats chronic heel pain that hasn't responded to conservative treatments like orthotics, physical therapy, or injections. Small particles block abnormal blood vessels in the plantar fascia, reducing inflammation and pain while allowing normal tissue healing.
treatments.recovery: Same-day discharge. Mild foot discomfort for a few days. Gradual improvement in pain over 2-6 weeks. Return to normal activities immediately. Physical therapy may enhance results.

categories.name: Oncology & Major Vascular
categories.description: Comprehensive treatments for cancer, peripheral artery disease, and aortic conditions.

treatments.title: Oncology Interventions
treatments.shortDescription: Minimally invasive treatments for cancer including chemoembolization and ablation.
treatments.fullDescription: Our oncology interventions include transarterial chemoembolization (TACE) for liver tumors, radioembolization (Y-90) for liver cancer, tumor ablation (radiofrequency and microwave) for liver, lung, and kidney tumors, and palliative procedures for pain and symptom control. These treatments target tumors directly while sparing healthy tissue.
benefits: Targets tumors directly with high local drug concentration
treatments.recovery: Varies by procedure. TACE and ablation typically require overnight stay. Post-embolization syndrome (fever, nausea) may occur for 2-3 days. Return to normal activities in 1-2 weeks. Imaging follow-up at 4-6 weeks.

treatments.title: Peripheral Vascular Revascularization
treatments.shortDescription: Angioplasty and stenting for peripheral artery disease and limb salvage.
treatments.fullDescription: Peripheral vascular revascularization treats narrowed or blocked arteries in the legs, arms, and kidneys. We use angioplasty (balloon dilation), stenting, and atherectomy to restore blood flow, relieving claudication (leg pain with walking), preventing limb amputation, and treating renovascular hypertension.
benefits: Relieves leg pain and improves walking distance
Prevents limb loss in critical ischemia
Minimally invasive - no large surgical incisions
Quick recovery compared to bypass surgery
treatments.recovery: Most procedures are outpatient or overnight stay. Groin access site heals in 3-5 days. Return to normal activities in 1 week. Antiplatelet medications required. Regular duplex ultrasound surveillance.

treatments.title: Visceral & Aortic Disease Treatment
treatments.shortDescription: Comprehensive treatment for aortic aneurysms and visceral vascular conditions.
treatments.fullDescription: We treat aortic diseases including abdominal and thoracic aortic aneurysms using EVAR and TEVAR (endovascular stent grafts). We also manage visceral vascular diseases including splenic, hepatic, and renal artery aneurysms, mesenteric ischemia, and visceral artery stenosis using angioplasty, stenting, and embolization.
treatments.recovery: EVAR/TEVAR typically requires 2-3 day hospital stay. Return to normal activities in 2-4 weeks. Lifelong CT surveillance required. Visceral interventions are often outpatient. Regular imaging follow-up essential.

items.question: What is endovascular treatment and how does it differ from traditional surgery?
items.answer: Endovascular treatment is a minimally invasive approach where procedures are performed inside blood vessels using thin catheters inserted through a small puncture (typically in the groin or wrist). Unlike traditional open surgery, there are no large incisions, no need to remove skull sections for brain procedures, and no organ removal for conditions like uterine fibroids. This means significantly less pain, minimal scarring, shorter hospital stays (often same-day discharge), and faster return to normal activities—typically within days rather than weeks or months.

items.question: What conditions do you treat at BEVA Clinic?
items.answer: We specialize in comprehensive endovascular treatments across multiple specialties: Neurovascular conditions (brain aneurysms, stroke, carotid artery disease, AVMs), Neuromodulation (Deep Brain Stimulation for Parkinson's disease, sleep apnea treatment), Urogenital and Pelvic conditions (uterine fibroids, enlarged prostate, varicose veins), Gastrointestinal issues (hemorrhoids), Musculoskeletal problems (knee osteoarthritis, plantar fasciitis), and Oncology/Vascular conditions (liver tumors, peripheral artery disease, aortic aneurysms). Our diverse expertise allows us to treat complex conditions that may not be suitable for traditional surgery.

items.question: Am I a candidate for endovascular treatment instead of traditional surgery?
items.answer: Many patients who are candidates for traditional surgery can also benefit from endovascular alternatives. Factors we evaluate include your specific diagnosis, vascular anatomy from imaging studies (CT, MRI, or angiography), overall health status, and previous treatments. Endovascular options are particularly beneficial for patients who are high-risk for open surgery, have conditions in difficult-to-reach anatomical locations, or wish to preserve organs (such as avoiding hysterectomy for fibroids). During your consultation, our specialists will review your complete medical history and imaging to recommend the optimal treatment approach.

items.question: What should I expect during the procedure?
items.answer: Most procedures are performed under local anesthesia with sedation, meaning you'll be comfortable but awake. A tiny puncture (under 5mm) is made in the groin or wrist to access blood vessels. Using real-time X-ray guidance, catheters are navigated to the treatment site. Procedures typically take 1-3 hours depending on complexity. You'll feel minimal discomfort—mostly pressure at the access site. After completion, the puncture is sealed with a special closure device or pressure dressing. Most patients can go home the same day or after overnight observation.

items.question: How should I prepare for my procedure?
items.answer: Preparation varies by procedure type. Generally, you'll need to fast for 6-8 hours before the procedure. We may ask you to temporarily stop certain medications like blood thinners (under medical supervision). Arrange for someone to drive you home, as you cannot drive for 24 hours after sedation. Wear comfortable clothing and bring a list of current medications, allergies, and previous imaging results. Our team will provide detailed pre-procedure instructions specific to your treatment during your consultation.

items.question: What is the recovery process like?
items.answer: Recovery is typically rapid compared to traditional surgery. Most patients experience mild discomfort at the access site (groin or wrist) for 2-3 days. You can usually resume light activities within 24-48 hours and return to work within 1-2 weeks. Specific restrictions include avoiding heavy lifting (over 5kg) and strenuous exercise for about one week. You'll have follow-up appointments at 1-4 weeks post-procedure, with imaging studies (ultrasound, CT, or MRI) scheduled at 3-6 months to confirm treatment success. Detailed recovery timelines are provided for each specific treatment.

items.question: Are endovascular procedures safe? What are the risks?
items.answer: Endovascular procedures are generally very safe with complication rates significantly lower than open surgery. Common minor effects include bruising at the puncture site and mild discomfort. Serious complications are rare (typically under 2-3%) and may include bleeding, infection, blood vessel injury, or reaction to contrast dye. Our specialists use advanced imaging guidance and protective devices (like embolic protection filters) to minimize risks. We conduct thorough pre-procedure assessments to ensure you're a suitable candidate and discuss all potential risks specific to your condition during consultation.

items.question: Will my insurance cover endovascular treatments?
items.answer: Most major insurance plans cover endovascular procedures, particularly when they are medically necessary alternatives to traditional surgery. Coverage varies by insurer and specific procedure. Our administrative team can help verify your benefits, obtain pre-authorization if required, and provide detailed cost estimates. We accept various international insurance plans and can assist with documentation for claims. For self-pay patients, we provide transparent pricing with no hidden fees. Contact us for a personalized insurance verification.

items.question: How do I choose between different treatment options for my condition?
items.answer: Our specialists take time to explain all appropriate treatment options for your specific condition, including endovascular approaches, traditional surgery, medications, or watchful waiting. We discuss the benefits, risks, recovery times, and success rates of each option. Our goal is to empower you with information to make an informed decision that aligns with your health goals and lifestyle.

items.question: What follow-up care is required after treatment?
items.answer: Follow-up care ensures optimal outcomes and monitors treatment effectiveness. Typically, you'll have an initial check-up 1-2 weeks post-procedure to assess the access site and recovery. Imaging follow-ups (ultrasound, CT, or MRI) are scheduled at 3-6 months and annually thereafter to confirm the treatment's success—such as confirming aneurysm occlusion, fibroid shrinkage, or vein closure. For implantable devices like DBS or sleep apnea stimulators, programming appointments optimize settings. Our team provides a personalized follow-up schedule and remains available for questions throughout your recovery.
